facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 191 of 1962 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 9, 10 and 12 of 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 426 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 191 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 9, 10 and 12 of 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 426 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellants are accused Nos. 1 to 10 and 12 in the Sessions Court, Mehsana.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are 11 in number were accused Nos. 1 to 10 and 12 in the Sessions Court, Mehsana.

facts.text: Village of Aithor has about 300 houses of Kadva Patidars and about 15 to 20 houses of Leva Patidars.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution may be stated thus In the village of Aithor there are about 300 houses of Kadva Patidars and about 15 to 20 houses of Leva Patidars.

facts.text: On January 16, 1961, at about 8 P.M., seven Leva Patidars came to the chowk where there is a pan shop cabin of Girdhar Shanker.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1961, at about 8 P.m. seven persons, who are Leva Patidars, came to the chowk where there is a pan shop cabin of Girdhar Shanker.

facts.text: The seven persons were Rama Bhupta, Lakha Madha, Hira Punja, Jetha Nagar, Parshottam Prabhuva, Manor Madha and Gova Shiva.

anchor.surface_text: These seven persons were, Rama Bhupta, Lakha Madha, Hira Punja, Jetha Nagar, Parshottam Prabhuva, Manor Madha and Gova Shiva.

facts.text: At the same time the 12 accused also came to that place.

anchor.surface_text: At the same-time the 12 accused also came to that place.

facts.text: Accused 1 to 6 were each armed with a muzzle loading gun.

anchor.surface_text: Accused 1 to 6 were each armed with a muzzle loading gun accused 7, 8, 11 and 12 were armed with sticks accused 9 and 10 were armed with dharias.

facts.text: Accused 7, 8, 11 and 12 were armed with sticks; accused 9 and 10 were armed with dharias.

anchor.surface_text: accused 7, 8, 11 and 12 were armed with sticks accused 9 and 10 were armed with dharias.

facts.text: Accused 1 to 4 fired their guns and Rama Bhupta fell down and died near the door of the cabin of Girdhar.

anchor.surface_text: Accused I to 4 fired their guns and Rama Bhupta fell down and died near the door of the cabin of Girdhar.

facts.text: Accused 5 and 6 fired their guns and Lakha Madha was injured.

anchor.surface_text: Accused 5 and 6 fired their guns and Lakha Madha was injured.

facts.text: Accused 1 fired his gun again and Jetha Nagar received injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Accused I fired his gun again and Jetha Nagar received injuries.

facts.text: Accused 5 and 6 fired again and Hira Punja was injured.

anchor.surface_text: Accused 5 and 6 fired again and Hira Punja was injured.

facts.text: Accused 7 to 12 were inciting accused 1 to 6 to kill all these persons.

anchor.surface_text: Accused 7 to 12 were inciting accused 1 to 6 to kill all these persons.

facts.text: Learned Sessions Judge held that Rama Bhupta was killed as a result of the firing by accused 1 to 4.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge held that Rama Bhupta was killed as a result of the firing by accused 1 to 4, that Lakha Madha was injured by the firing by accused 5 and 6

facts.text: Sessions Judge held that Lakha Madha was injured by the firing by accused 5 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: that Lakha Madha was injured by the firing by accused 5 and 6, that Jetha Nagar was injured by the firing by accused 1, that Hira Punja was injured by the firing by accused 5 and 6

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted all the accused under S. 302 read with S. 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He acquitted all the accused under S. 302, read with S. 149, of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted accused 1 to 4 under S. 302 read with S. 34 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2000 each.

anchor.surface_text: but convicted accused I to 4 under s. 302, read with S. 34, of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to imprisonment for life and to a fine of Rs. 2,000 each

facts.text: High Court convicted accused 1 to 4 under S. 302 read with ss. 301 and 34 IPC and confirmed life imprisonment but set aside fine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court convicted accused I to 4 under s. 302, read with ss. 301 and 34, of the Indian Penal Code and confirmed the sentence of life imprisonment passed on them, but set aside the fine imposed on them.

facts.text: High Court convicted accused 5 to 12 under S. 302 read with ss. 301 and 34 and also under S. 302 read with S. 149 IPC and sentenced to life.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the other accused i.e., accused 5 to 12, are concerned, they were convicted under s. 302, read with ss. 301 and 34, of the Indian Penal Code and also under s. 302, read with S. 149, of the said Code. In the result, the High Court sentenced all the accused to imprisonment for life for the said offences.

facts.text: High Court found common intention of the accused was to kill Madha, accused 1 to 4 shot at Rama mistaking him for Madha as Rama dressed similarly.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the common intention of the accused was to kill Madha, that accused 1 to 4 shot at Rama mistaking him for Madha, as Rama had dressed himself in the habiliments similar to those in which Madha used to dress himself

facts.text: It is common case that if conviction of accused 1 to 4 under 302/34/301 set aside, all acquitted on major offences.

anchor.surface_text: It is common case that if the conviction of accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with s. 34 and s. 301, of the Indian Penal Code, was set aside, all the accused would have to be acquitted in regard to the major offences.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants contends no common intention to kill Rama, but killed under mistake he was Madha.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal Mr. Chari, learned counsel for the appellants, contends that accused I to 4 could not be convicted under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code, as there was no common intention to kill Rama, but Rama was killed under the mistake that he was Madha.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held accused 12 caused stick injuries to Lakha.

anchor.surface_text: that accused 12 caused stick injuries to Lakha and that accused 8 caused injury on the tongue of Parshottam Prabhuva.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held the 12 accused constituted an unlawful assembly with common intention not to kill Rama Bhupta but only Madha.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge also held that the 12 accused constituted an unlawful assembly, but their common intention was not to kill Rama Bhupta but only Madha who was present in the chowk.

facts.text: State of Gujarat filed appeals against acquittal of accused 5 to 12 under 302/149.

anchor.surface_text: the State of Gujarat filed appeals against the acquittal of accused 5 to 12 under S. 302, read with s. 149, of the Indian Penal Code.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 9, 10 and 12 of 1962

issues.text: interesting question involving the construction of s. 34, read with s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises an interesting question involving the companystruction of s. 34, read with s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: whether the conviction of accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with ss. 34 and 301, of the Indian Penal Code, was correct

anchor.surface_text: It is common case that if the conviction of accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with s. 34 and s. 301, of the Indian Penal Code, was set aside, all the accused would have to be acquitted in regard to the major offences. [...] The only question, therefore, is whether the conviction of accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with ss. 34 and 301, of the Indian Penal Code, was correct.

issues.text: whether accused 1 to 4 could be convicted under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code, as there was no common intention to kill Rama, but Rama was killed under the mistake that he was Madha

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal Mr. Chari, learned counsel for the appellants, contends that accused I to 4 could not be convicted under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code, as there was no common intention to kill Rama, but Rama was killed under the mistake that he was Madha.

issues.text: whether the provisions of s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code can be invoked in the circumstances of the case

anchor.surface_text: He further argues that the provisions of s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code cannot be invoked in the circumstances of the case.

issues.text: whether the committing of a mistake was a part of the common intention, but whether it was done in furtherance of the common intention

anchor.surface_text: But the question is not, as we have pointed out, whether the committing of a mistake was a part of the common intention, but whether it was done in furtherance of the common intention.

issues.text: the impact of S. 301 of the Indian Penal Code on s. 34 thereof

anchor.surface_text: Now let us see the impact of S. 301 of the Indian Penal Code on s. 34 thereof.

arguments.claim: When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all each is liable as if done by him alone; applies even to killing under mistaken identity

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code reads When a criminal act is done by several persons, in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.

arguments.claim: Common intention implies pre-arranged plan inferred from conduct; criminal act in concert pursuant to plan

anchor.surface_text: This being the principle, it is clear to their Lordships that common intention within the meaning of the section implies a pre-arranged plan, and to convict the accused of an offence applying the section it should be proved that the criminal act was done in concert pursuant to the pre-arranged plan.

arguments.claim: Killing under mistaken impression of identity is in furtherance of common intention to kill intended victim

anchor.surface_text: If that much is conceded we do not see any justification why the killing of another under a mistaken impression of identity is not in furtherance of the common intention to kill the intended victim.

arguments.claim: S.301 IPC has no application as accused intended to kill the person they shot at though under misapprehension of identity

holdings.text: when accused I to 4 shot at Rama they shot at him in furtherance of their common intention to kill Madha

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that without the aid of s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code it can be held that when accused I to 4 shot at Rama they shot at him in furtherance of their common intention to kill Madha.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'in furtherance' as advancement or promotion of common intention; applies to bona fide mistaken identity killing via illustrations like shooting sentry or wrong person/twin; distinguishes from private vengeance

holdings.text: s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code has no application to the present case

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that s. 301 of the Indian Penal Code has no application to the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.301 (transfer of malice) requires no intention or knowledge of death of actual victim; here accused intended death of targeted person despite mistaken identity, satisfying ss.299/300 directly

holdings.text: all the accused are liable under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons we hold that all the accused are liable under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies S.34 to facts of common intention to kill Madha with shooting of Rama in furtherance; S.301 unnecessary; upholds convictions as per common case

precedents.cited_proposition: definition of 'criminal act' in section 34 of IPC as united criminal behaviour resulting in a criminal offence
precedents.cited_holding: A criminal act means that united criminal behaviour which results in something for which an individual would be punishable if it were all done by himself alone, that is, in a criminal offence.

precedents.citation: Mahbub Shah v. King-Emperor 1 L.R. 72 I.A. 148, 153

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee in Mahbub Shah v. King- Emperor 1  laid down the following companyditions for its application To invoke the aid of s. 34 successfully, it must be shown that the criminal act companyplained against was done by one of the accused persons in the furtherance of the companymon intention of all if this is shown, then liability for the crime may be imposed on any one of the persons in the same manner as if the act were done by him alone. Take L.R. 72 I.A. 148, 153.

precedents.cited_proposition: conditions for invoking section 34 IPC: criminal act done in furtherance of common intention of all, implying pre-arranged plan
